fields.name: Welcome to Recollection CSS

fields.body:
Embed and Share

Just copy-paste to embed your interface in any webpage. Provide your users with novel and intuitive ways to explore your content

Generate Views

Generate distinct interactive visual interfaces to your digital collections, including maps and timelines, and sophisticated faceted navigation.

Recollection is a free platform for generating and customizing views, (interactive maps, timelines, facets, tag clouds) that allow users to experience your digital collections.

Request Free Account
Watch Screencast
Get Started

Import Collections

Ingest collections from spreadsheets or MODS records. Upload from your desktop or import them from a URL.

The mission of the National Digital Information Infrastructure and Preservation Program (NDIIPP) is to develop a national strategy to collect, preserve and make available significant digital content, especially information that is created in digital form only, for current and future generations. In 2008, the NDIIPP partners shared content through a simple web page. In order to explore more useful tools and processes for sharing diverse content across partners’ collections, the Library began a pilot project in 2009 with Zepheira to develop an environment that can be used to collect and explore information about digital collections. The result is a software platform that we are calling Recollection.



Recollection is built on the Freemix Platform which leverages Web-based open standards and "best of breed" open source tools, many of which Zepheira are actively leading. We gratefully acknowledge our debt the Free/Libre/Open Source Software (FLOSS) community. The Freemix Platform makes use of the following Web standard and FLOSS projects:

Freemix leverages RDF to facilitate the integration of data drawn from diverse sources. RDF is an open, W3C standard that provides a common way for data to be shared and reused across application, enterprise, and community boundaries. The data inside your organization is too important for you to lock it into proprietary formats. Its your data, take it back.

The MIT Simile project is focused on designing tools to facilitate interoperability among digital asset distributed across individual, community, and institutional stores. Freemix builds on Simile's Exhibit project to provide simple and easy to use interfaces that allow you to stitch together data and display it in a manner than makes sense to you.

Data exists in more than just Databases. Web pages, news feeds, spreadsheets, email, your contacts lists, etc. are all useful data sources that can be combined to provide new insight. Akara is an umbrella project for a set of robust, core components that provide generalized data processing and transformation capabilities. Akara provides a means of taking data traditionally locked up in an application and enables you to Freemix it.

Django is a Python Web framework that "encourages rapid development and clean, pragmatic design." We couldn't agree more.

Pinax is a set of Django-based applications for rapidly developing Web sites. Although Freemix is rapidly growing past Pinax, we gratefully acknowledge the assistance provided by the Pinax community.

Contents

  1. What is Recollection?
  2. Who uses Recollection?
  3. What kind of data can I import into Recollection?
  4. Can I get my data out of Recollection?
  5. Does Recollection copy my content?
  6. How do I get started?
  7. Where is Recollection hosted?
  8. What are the System Requirements?

What is Recollection?

Recollection is a social networking site for digital content. Use Recollection to slice, show and rapidly share data with your colleagues and friends.

Using Recollection, you can easily transform data and create compelling Web pages with facets. You can easily mashup content in a list or a table, or on a map, timeline, scatter plot or pie chart.

Who uses Recollection?

Anyone who creates and analyzes data will quickly see the power of Recollection. Those who wish to share data with colleagues or in a group will find Recollection invaluable.

Whether you want to share spreadsheets with scientific findings or lists of artwork or photos in a more Web-friendly way, you can rapidly expose your content using Recollection. If you wish to securely and privately share data with only your family and friends, please contact solutions@zepheira.com, our partner for creating secure and custom solutions based on Recollection.

What kind of data can I import into Recollection?

For the moment, two types of files can be imported into Recollection: XML MODS and rectangular spreadsheets. XML MODS files must be valid XML and follow the Metadata Object Description Schema (MODS).

Simplistic Excel spreadsheets may be used to get data into Recollection, but every version of Excel's proprietary format cannot be supported. By "simplistic", we mean that a single worksheet can have contiguous rows and columns that form a rectangle. This "rectangular spreadsheet" can have blank columns to the left and right and an optional title and subtitle at the top, as long as they are in single cells.

Best results will be obtained from data with less than 1,000 records, e.g. spreadsheets with less than 1,000 rows. Larger amounts of data will result in significant time delays or even a failure to load the data set.

While data standards greatly improve the opportunity to provide data transformation, consistency of implementation for any given standard is not guaranteed. Please visit the Troubleshooting Guide to read tips on how to submit files for review and further testing support.

Can I get my data out of Recollection?

Absolutely! However, Recollection does not store your original data files. You should always back up your original files and not rely on Recollection to store them for you.

Recollection stores a converted copy of your data in the JSON file format, augmented with some additional information used to make Collections. You can download your data in that format, in RDF/XML, semantic wikitext, tab-separated values, or Exhibit JSON.

Does Recollection copy my content?

Recollection stores a converted copy of your data in the JSON file format, augmented with some additional information used to make Collections. You can see exactly what Recollection stores by selecting the "JSON" link from a data profile visible on your Profile page.

How do I get started?

Recollection is offered as a software as a service, or SaaS, please go to the home page to get started. There you can sign up, search profiles, invite someone to be your friend, make a tribe, join an existing tribe, and perform account management.

We make it easy on you. See the tutorial screencasts or the user guide available in the help section to help you get started.

Where is Recollection hosted?

Recollection relies on the services of Rackspace, a San Antonio, Texas–based company that provides enterprise-level Web infrastructure and managed services to businesses of all sizes. Serving more than 10,000 customers through its six data centers worldwide, Rackspace integrates the industry’s best technologies to meet each customer’s needs, and it backs up its tools and services with a commitment that it calls Fanatical Supporttm

What are the System Requirements?

Recollection makes every attempt to support the following Web browsers: Microsoft Internet Explorer v.7 & 8, Firefox v.3.x and Safari v.3.x. Opera v.9.x, Camino v.1.6.x, Firefox v.2.x mostly work but are not as thoroughly tested and not officially supported. Internet Explorer v.6 does not work with some of the software used by Recollection and so we cannot support it.

Recollection currently supports the US English (en-US) locale. Internationalization efforts are underway.

Views

Views are like lenses which allow users to view resource information in various ways, such as plotted on a map or shown on a timeline. The list below describes the types of views available for use in Recollection. To see an example of each view, click on the thumbnail image provided.

List

The list view is the default view that appears when a data set is imported into Recollection; it displays a sorted list of all of the data records in a file.

Map

For data files with location information, Recollection can display data records plotted as points on a map to allow for geographical exploration of the data.

Scatter Plot

A scatter plot is a type of display using coordinates to display values for two variables for a set of data. The data is displayed as a collection of points, each having the value of one variable determining the position on the horizontal axis and the value of the other variable determining the position on the vertical axis.

Table

The table view organizes and displays in table format. Table columns can be easily sorted to display information ordered in different ways.

Timeline

Data sets with temporal information can be plotted on a timeline and explored interactively using this time-based view.

Pie Chart

Quantitative data can be displayed and explored using a pie chart view. As the data set is narrowed using facet selections, the pie chart view will change to reflect new quantities.

Facets

Facets provide users with a way to narrow their search. There are several types of facets that you may choose to include when building your Recollection view. To see an example of each view, click on the thumbnail image provided.

Search Box

Use this to give you the ability to search any part of a record.

List

Creates a list from a designated field that you can use to narrow your search.

Tag Cloud

Creates a tag cloud from a designated field that you can use to narrow their search.

Logo

Allows you to place a logo available via URL on your Recollection view.

Text

Allows you to add descriptive text to your Recollection view.

Read

The Recollection user guide is the best source of information that will help you use this system to:

  • Rapidly combine private and public information, style it, and share it
  • Make collections easier to find, access and share
  • Enable new insights into patterns and relationships inherent to data
  • Build a network of trust and participation around a common goal

The Recollection FAQ page can help you find quick answers to specific questions about the site.


Watch

The following video provides a high level overview of the Recollection platform and its capabilities.

Create

Don't have any data to get started? Don't worry, you can use some of ours! First, download any of the following sample files ...

  • An Excel spreadsheet of the NDIIPP partners
  • An XML mods file of California Elections in 2004
  • A small database snapshot of the University of Louisville, Jean Thomas, The Traipsin' Woman Collection

Now, upload this file from your hard drive to Recollection!


Follow

You can track data files and Collections as they are uploaded; just subscribe to the appropriate news feed!

  • Track the latest Collections added to the system
  • Track latest data files added to the system
  • The most recent Collections created by a particular user can be tracked by:
    • http://recollection.zepheira.com/feeds/views_atom/username
  • Similarly, the latest data files uploaded by a particular user can be tracked by subscribing to the following news feed pattern
    • http://recollection.zepheira.com/feeds/data_atom/username

1. Overview of Recollection

Recollection is a tool for creating new interfaces, relationships, and access points for digital resources. Using Recollection, you can expose, visualize, and manage data currently stored in Excel spreadsheets or XML MODS. You can view this data in a list or a table, on a map, or in timeline, scatter plot or pie chart, and you can embed the views you create in existing websites.

The steps to create a Recollection View are:

  • Upload or link to data which exists in an Excel spreadsheet or XML MODS
  • Describe your data
  • Augment date and place information
  • Publish a URI of your data
  • Build a data view
  • Select facets (i.e. tag clouds) and views (i.e. maps and charts) for your data
  • Preview your work
  • Publish a URI of your Recollection view
  • Share and embed your Recollection view

Whether you want to share spreadsheets with scientific findings or lists of artwork or photos in a more Web-friendly way, you can rapidly expose your content using Recollection.

1.1 Supported Browsers

Recollection makes every attempt to support the following Web browsers: Microsoft Internet Explorer v.7 and v.8, Firefox v.3.x, Safari v.3.x and Safari v.4.x.

The following web browsers mostly work, but are not as thoroughly tested and not officially supported: Opera v.9.x, Camino v.1.6.x, Firefox v.2.x.

Internet Explorer v.6 does not work with some of the software used by Recollection and is not supported.

2. Creating a Recollection account

Creating an account allows you to access all the features of Recollection, create your own personal profile, save the views you create, and connect with other users and groups who have similar interests.

2.1 Signing up

Recollection is currently in invitational Beta and only accessible to NDIIPP partners, Library of Congress employees, and other authorized users. To gain access to Recollection with an authorized account, please send us an email (including your desired username) to ndiippaccess@loc.gov. Our team will respond within a few days with your account information.

2.2 Logging in

If your user account has been created, you may log in by clicking "Login" at the top right corner of the Recollection Home Page Home Page. This will take you to the Recollection Login Page shown in Figure 1 where you can log in in one of two ways:

  1. To use a previously created user name and password, enter these in the Log In section on the left side of the Log In page and click "Log in".
  2. To use an OpenID account, enter the OpenID in the box provided and click "Log in". Not OpenID enabled? An OpenID account may be created by visiting the "Get started now" link provided.


Figure 1. Recollection Login Screen

See Settings: Managing Your Account for more details on setting up your Recollection account.

2.3 Verify Email Address

In order to use the "forgot password" feature you will need to have a verified email address for your account. Please remember to verify your email address by taking the following steps:

  • Visit the Settings Page by clicking on the "Settings" link at the top right corner of any page.
  • Type an email address in the text box provided.
  • Click the "Add" button. A verification email will be sent to the account indicated within 5 minutes.
  • Click on the confirmation link provided in the email to complete the verification process.

3. Create A Recollection View

There are a number of steps to creating a Recollection View, each of which is explained in more detail in this section:

  • First, you upload data to Recollection using previously created files which exist on your desktop or which are accessible via URL.
  • Then, you edit and augment your data to prepare it to be used successfully when creating a Recollection View plotted on a map, a timeline or other available view options.
  • Publishing your data will save it in Recollection for use by you and others.
  • After your data is published, you will be prompted to "Create a Collection". During this step you will create and publish your Recollection View.

3.1 Upload Your Data

You can upload a data file to Recollection, by starting from either your Home Page or the Data tab. Click the "Upload Data" button displayed. You will be directed to the "Upload Data" page shown in Figure 2. For more information on the supported file types and sizes see Section 3.1.1: Details of Supported File Types.


Figure 2. Upload Data

3.1.1 Details of Supported File Types

For the moment, two types of files can be imported into Recollection: simplistic Excel spreadsheets and XML MODS are supported formats.

Simplistic Excel spreadsheets may be used to get data into Recollection, but every version of Excel's proprietary format cannot be supported. By "simplistic", we mean that a single worksheet can have contiguous rows and columns that form a rectangle. This "rectangular spreadsheet" can have blank columns to the left and right and an optional title and subtitle at the top, as long as they are in single cells.

Best results will be obtained from data files of 1MB in size or smaller. Larger amounts of data will result in significant time delays or even a failure to load the data set.

3.1.2 Add a File From the Desktop

  • Click "Choose File" under the "From Your Computer" section on the left-hand side of the screen.
  • Locate and select the file from your hard drive.
  • Click "Upload".
  • Recollection loads your file into the "Describe" screen to allow you to describe your data.

3.1.3: Add a File From a URL:

  • Type or paste the URL into the text box which appears below the words "From the Web" on the right-hand side of the Upload Data page.
  • Click "Retrieve".
  • Recollection loads your file into the "Describe" screen to allow you to describe your data.

3.1.4 Troubleshooting Data File Uploads

If you encounter a problem uploading your file, please use the following troubleshooting tips to try to correct the problem:

For XML MODS:

  • XML MODS files must be valid XML. Try the validator at Validome.
  • Check that they follow the Metadata Object Description Schema (MODS) schema. For more information about the MODS schema can be found at the MODS home page.

For spreadsheets:

  • Remove any data that is not in a solid rectangular area. This includes white space, page titles, scattered cells, and additional worksheets.
  • Check that your formatting is consistent throughout each column (e.g. column is all in date format, currency format, etc. as appropriate)
  • Make sure that data of the same type but in different columns is formatted consistently (e.g. dates in different columns are in the same date format).

If you have a file that you think should work after troubleshooting please send us your file with some information to help us debug the problem. Send your file to ndiippaccess@loc.gov with the following information:

  • Your computer's operating system name and version.
  • The name and version of the application used to create the file.
  • Please copy and paste information from the "About" page of the application used to create the file. For example, if your file was created in Excel, choose the "Excel" menu option, then "About Excel". Copy and past the version information that appears on this screen.
  • Don't forget to attach the file itself to your email!

3.2 Describe and Publish Your Data


Figure 3. Describe Your Data

After successfully loading the data, you will land on a "Describe Your Data" screen. In a green "progress band" at the top of your page (shown in Figure 4) you will see the three steps necessary to complete the data upload process: (1) Replace allows you to replace the data you just uploaded with a new data set and start over; (2) Describe; and (3) Publish. Detailed instructions for each step are outlined below:


Figure 4. Progress Band

The "Describe Your Data" screen allows you to review the data fields and "describe" them to support creation of your Recollection View. During the Describe step there are a number of options for modifying the data:

3.2.1: Hide a Field

To hide a field so it does not show in the final Recollection View, uncheck the check box next to the data field in the "Enabled" column. Note: Fields already unchecked are typically fields or data that gets added by the system during the upload process but does not need to display.

3.2.2: Rename Data Set Title

To rename the title of your data set, click the pencil icon or the actual text of the current title. Type new text as desired. Hit the Tab key or click on another part of the screen to complete this process.

3.2.3: Rename Field

  • Click the pencil icon or the actual text of the field name to be changed in the "Field Name" column as shown in Figure 5. An editable text box appears.
  • Edit the text as desired.
  • Click the "Rename" button to rename the field.
  • Click "Cancel" to revert to the last saved version of the field name.


Figure 5. Rename a Field

3.2.4: Change a Data Type

Data types are used to drive view features such as the ability to plot data on a map or a timeline. By changing data types, you indicate to Recollection what kind of data it is dealing with so that it can be properly processed. For instance, to plot a data point on a timeline, it must be indicated as "date/time" format. It is advisable to indicate data types during the Describe step so that you do not have to edit your data set again later if you decide to add a new data-driven view when building your Recollection View. Note that your data must be in the proper format in order for Recollection to display it in the appropriate view. If you choose to alter the data type, you should remove the default value of "text" to ensure the Recollection View display functions properly. If you are unsure whether your data is in the proper format for display see Section 3.2.5: Augment Your Data.

To change the data type for a field:

  • In the Types column, click the pulldown list next to the data field to be updated.
  • Add a property type for the data field by clicking on the desired type.

Repeat this process until all data field types are described as desired.

3.2.5 Augment Your Data

If you plan to view your data on a map or timeline when creating a Recollection View, you will need to ensure that your data is in the proper format to support these visualizations.

  • Plotting data on a map requires a latitude and longitude. Example: 37.386,-122.084 will map to Mountain View, California.
  • Showing data on a timeline requires the dates be formatted in ISO8601 format. Example: 2008-04-01T00:00:00+0000 will be plotted on a timeline at April 1, 2008.

If your file doesn't have data in these formats or if you are not sure it is in the proper format, Recollection can augment of transform some location and date information into the proper format. Note that Recollection never changes existing data in your file during the augmentation process. Recollection only adds columns of new data to your file. You may only augment data when loading or editing the data in the Recollection tool, before you start creating views.

3.2.5.1 Augment Dates

If your data has any of the following date formats, you may augment the data in this stage to allow plotting on a timeline when building a Recollection View in a later stage:

International unambiguous, Y2K-safe formats such as:

  • YYYY (eg 1997)
  • YYYY-MM (eg 1997-07)
  • YYYY-MM-DD (eg 1997-07-16)
  • YYYY-MM-DDThh:mmTZD (eg 1997-07-16T19:20+01:00

A subset of ISO-6601 dates (as prevalent in LC MODS):

  • YYYDDMM
  • YYYYDDMMhhmmss

Also basic US convention, Y2K-safe year dates: MM/DD/YYYY

To augment your date data so that it may be placed on a timeline:

  • Click the "Augment Data" button at the bottom of the Describe screen. See Figure 6.
  • Provide a name for the new field in the text box at the top of the screen, for example: Augmented Date.
  • Click on the timeline image to indicate the type of view the data will be used in. The current field names of your data are displayed on the right. By clicking the "+", choose the field that contains any of the date information listed above. Note: Currently date information must be contained in one field to perform date augmentation.
  • Scroll down and click the "Create" button at the bottom left hand corner of the data augmentation popup window to create the new field. See Figure 7
    • .
  • You will now see a new row in your data profile. Click the "Refresh Augmented Data" button at the bottom of the Describe screen to generate data values for the new field. If your augmentation is successful you will see dates formatted in ISO8601 in the value column.
  • If your augmentation is not successful you will receive an error message at the top of the screen. Please send the error message and the format of your data or the data itself to ndiippaccess@loc.gov.


Figure 6. Augment Data Button

3.2.5.2 Augment Locations

If your data has any of the following location information, you may augment the data in this stage to allow plotting on a map when building a Recollection View in a later stage:

Locations:

  • city, state
  • city, state, zip
  • city, country
  • zip code

Note: Location augmentation can fail if any sub-component does not appear in the geocoding database used for automatic latitude/longitude look-ups. Also, at this time location augmentation will not work for zip codes in zip+4 format.

  • Click the "Augment Data" button at the bottom of the Describe screen. See Figure 6.
  • Provide a name for the new field in the text box at the top of the screen, for example: Augmented Location.
  • Click on the map image to indicate the type of view the field or fields will be used in.
  • The current field names of your data are displayed on the right. By clicking the "+", choose the field or fields that contain any of the location information listed above. The chosen field from which to derive the new value will move to the left-hand column. If your location data appears in more than one field (City, State, Country), select all of those fields to create more precise latitude and longitude data augmentations. For best results, drag and drop the chosen field names so they are ordered as they would typically appear on an address label.
  • Continue selecting fields in this manner until you have indicated all the fields that will be used to derive the data values in the new field.
  • Click the "Create" button at the bottom left hand corner of the screen to create the new field. See Figure 7.
  • You will now see a new row in your data profile. Click the "Refresh Augmented Data" button at the bottom of the Describe screen to generate data values for the new field. If your augmentation is successful you will see latitude and longitude numbers in the value column of your new field.
  • If your augmentation is not successful you will receive an error message at the top of the screen. Please send the error message and the format of your data or the data itself to ndiippaccess@loc.gov.


Figure 7. Data Augmentation Popup Window

3.2.5.3 Extract Lists

If you have multiple data values which appear in one field, these values can be extracted for individual use in facets or views.

A list can be extracted using the following steps:

  • Load or edit a file that has one or more fields which contain a list of multiple values.
  • Click the "Augment Data" button.
  • Type a field name into the text box provided.
  • Click on the "List" icon to choose the list extraction service.
  • Select the source field which contains the list of multiple values to be extracted.
  • Select a pre-populated pattern from the drop down list. If none of the patterns match the pattern of your data:
  • Click on the "build a pattern" link to create a custom list extraction.
  • Enter your pattern or a single character delimiter if appropriate. When entering a character delimiter, remember to include spaces if they are present (e.g. " === ") Advanced custom patterns can be created by entering a regular expression.
  • Select the pattern type from the pull down list. Valid choices are "pattern" if a regular expression has been entered or "delimited" if a character or string of characters has been entered as a delimiter. If you have chosen from the pre-populated pattern pick list you do not need to select a pattern type as it has already been set for you.
  • Click the "Create" button to create the new field to hold the extracted values.
  • Click the "Refresh Augmented Data" button to generate extracted values for the new field.
  • If your augmentation is not successful you will receive an error message at the top of the screen. Please send the error message and the format of your data or the data itself to ndiippaccess@loc.gov.

3.2.6: Publish Your Data

Once you have finished describing and augmenting your data, in order to save it in Recollection you will need publish it to the Web. Your data will be given a URL within the Recollection tool and a data profile is created and added to your collections of data.

To publish your data in Recollection:

  • Click "Publish" in the progress band toward to top of the page to proceed to this step.
  • If you did not give your data set a name in the Describe step you will be prompted to enter a name for the new data profile in the text box provided.
  • The URL for your data profile is shown and you are given the option to proceed and create a new collection or upload more data.

3.3: View Additional Records

The Describe screen displays the first record of the data file that was submitted for upload. You may want to check the other records in your data file to ensure they look as expected. To do this:

  • Click on the "Next Record" button at the bottom right corner of the Describe screen. The number of records that was uploaded is displayed and the current record number you are viewing is indicated (for example "5 of 45").
  • Navigate through the records as desired using "Next Record" and "Previous Record" buttons.

3.4 Working With Data Sets

Each time you upload and describe data, Recollection creates a new data set. Once a data set has been uploaded to Recollection and published, you can view the data, edit your data set, or delete data. You can also choose to build new Recollection Views, as multiple Recollection views can be built off of the same data set to afford you different views of the same data. You can even build a new Recollection view off of a another user's data set if you wish.

The "Your Data" section under the Data tab shows all of data sets you have uploaded and which are available to work with in Recollection. Your data sets can also be viewed from your Home Page.

3.4.1 View a Data Set

To view a data set:

  • Locate the data set to be viewed in the list shown on your Home Page or the Data tab.
  • Click on the linked name of the data set you would like to view.
  • A read-only display of your data properties and descriptions will appear.

3.4.2 Edit a Data Set

To edit a data set:

  • Locate the data set to be edited in the list shown on your Home Page or the Data tab.
  • Click the "Edit" link to the right of the data set to be edited.
  • You will be directed to the Describe screen and can edit data types, names, or augment additional data as needed.

Note: Updates to data in your data sets will not be reflected in Recollection collections automatically, but can be updated by replacing the data set file with a newer version as needed.

3.4.3 Replace a Data Set

To replace a data set:

  • Locate the data set to be edited in the list shown on your Home Page or the Data tab.
  • Click the "Edit" link to the right of the data set to be edited.
  • You will be directed to the Describe screen.
  • Click Replace in the green progress bar.
  • Follow the instructions to upload a file. Once your file has been uploaded, you can proceed to the Describe step where you can update file name, change field types and names, augment data, and republish your file.

    Once republished, your data set will now contain the replaced data. Warning: Please be careful when replacing data. Only replace data sets with ones that have the exact same format. If you replace your original data set with one that has a different format you may break existing views built by you and by others.

3.4.4 Delete a Data Set

If data sets are out of date or no longer needed, they may be deleted. To delete an existing data set:

  • Locate the data set to be deleted in the list shown on your Home Page or on the Data tab.
  • Click the "Delete" link next to the data set you would like to delete.
  • After confirming the delete prompt, the data set is removed from your data sets list. This action cannot be undone.

Important Note: Deleting a data set causes all Recollection views associated with the data set to be deleted as well. You will receive a warning message if there are multiple views that have been created from the data set you are trying to delete. Please review this carefully before proceeding. Consider that if other users have built Recollection view using your data set, their work will also be deleted.

3.5 Build Your Recollection View From a New Data Set

Once you have completed the Describe process and have saved your data set into the Recollection system, you must take an additional step to "Build" a Recollection View so that others may interact with your data using the Recollection tools. There are two ways to proceed to the Build step: either continue on immediately after publishing data by clicking on the "Create a Collection" button or if you didn't immediately do this upon publishing a data set, you may also click on the data tab from your Home page, and click the "Build" link next to the data set you would like to use to create a new Recollection View as shown in Figure 8. When you open up the Build screen, you will see the green progress band again at the top. This now says (1) Describe (you may return to further Describe your data here); (2) Build (described in this section); (3) Preview (to test out what you have Built so far; (4) Publish (to publish your Recollection View).


Figure 8. Locate Build Link

During the Build process, you are building the Recollection View, essentially forming the user interface view for your uploaded data. You can determine the general look and feel of your Recollection View, how the user can search, narrow results, and view timelines and/or maps. You may add several facets or none before leaving this section. Build options are

3.5.1: Pick a Canvas

The first step in building in a Recollection view is to pick a canvas. A canvas is a template which dictates the layout of your screen. You will be presented with a variety of canvas options in a pop-up box as shown in Figure 9. To pick a canvas, simply click on the layout you prefer and you will be taken to a Build screen which reflects your choice and allows you to begin the Build process.


Figure 9. Pick a Canvas

3.5.2: Add a Title and Subtitle

Titles and Subtitles will be displayed on your published Recollection page. The Title defaults to the same name as your data file, but this can be modified at any time by following the directions below.

  • Click on the title or the words "Click to Edit Subtitle..." near the top left corner of the screen to change the title or subtitle.
  • Type the desired text.
  • Hitting the "return" or "tab" keys or clicking on any other part of the screen accepts the changes.
  • To create additional edits, simply click on the words again and type in changes.

3.5.3: Add Facets

Facets add visual elements to the page and provide users with a way to narrow the information presented. You may place facets to the right, left or above the main section of the interface depending on the canvas selection you have made. There are several types of facets that you may add:

  • Search box: use this to give you the ability to search any part of a record
  • List: creates a list from a designated field that you can use to narrow your search
  • Tag Cloud: Creates a tag cloud from a designated field that you can use to narrow their search
  • Logo: Allows you to place a logo available via URL directly into your Recollection view
  • Text: Allows you to add descriptive text to your Recollection view

To add facets which will appear in your published Recollection view:

  • Click on "Add a Facet" in the area of the screen where the navigation tool should be placed. These will be shown at the top, left or right portions of the screen depending on the canvas selection you have made at the beginning of the Build process.
  • Select the type of facet that should be added: search, list, cloud, logo, or text.
  • For list and cloud facets, select the property that will drive the navigation for the selected facet. For example, if navigating the information by state is desired, select the data field that contains state information.
  • For logo facets there are three settings:
    • Image Source: Enter the URL of the logo you want to display.
    • Text Alternate: Enter the words that should appear when you mouse over the image, when the image is unavailable or when someone is using a text reader.
    • Target Link: Enter the URL the user should be taken to if they click on the image in your finished Recollection view.
  • A placeholder for the selected facet will appear in the appropriate portion of the screen. For convenience, facet type, property name, number of fields containing values, and number of fields missing values are displayed.


Figure 10. Add Facets

3.5.4: Remove Facets

Facets may be removed at any time during the Build process. To remove a facet:

  • Click the down arrow which appears at the top right corner of the facet that should be removed.
  • Click "Delete".
  • The facet will disappear from view.


Figure 11. Remove Facets

3.5.5: Rename Facets

Facet names default to the original property label, but these may be changed if desired. To rename a facet:

  • Click the down arrow which appears at the top right corner of the facet that should be renamed.
  • Click the "Rename" link.
  • Type in the new name for the facet.
  • Click "OK" to accept changes.
  • The new facet name will appear at the top of the facet.


Figure 12. Rename Facets

3.5.6: Add a View

Views are like lenses which allow users to create various visualizations of information, for instance to show all of the records in one list, or data plotted on a map or a timeline. The default view is the list view.

3.5.7: Set List View Preferences

A list view, which simply presents a list of records in your data set, is added as the default view option. To modify preferences for the list view:

  • Select the List tab above the data fields list.
  • Hide any fields that you do not want displayed by unchecking the box next to the associated data field. For instance, with files that have a large number of data fields, you may want to hide some fields that are not of interest to your intended audience to make your Recollection View less cluttered.
  • To add a title which will appear at the top of each record in the list view, click "edit" in the Title bar at the top of the data fields list. Select a data field from the pulldown menu which contains the data to be displayed as a title. Select "OK" to add the title field.
  • Data fields may be reordered by clicking on the field to be moved and dragging it to the desired location.

When done, you may want to click on Preview in the green bar to see how your list view appears. When previewing you will notice an option at the top of the list called "grouped as sorted". When this box is checked, your list is divided by subheadings based on the sort order of the list.

3.5.8: Add a Map View

Map View data pre-requisite: Your file must contain latitude and longitude values and the field type set to "location" during the Describe step in order for data points to appear in your map view. If you do not have lat, long values or are not sure if they are in the proper format for mapping, see Section 3.2.5: Augment Your Data.


Figure 13. Add a View

To add a map view:

  • Click "Add a View" next to the List View tab, then select "Map".
  • Click the radio button in the "Lat,Lng" column next to the field that displays your latitude and longitude data. This enables values to be plotted on a map.
  • If you would like map pins to display in different colors based on property values, click the radio button in the "Color" column to create a color-coded map legend. Click on the "clear" text link directly below the Color column header to remove all color coding.
  • Once plotted on a map, each of the pin points can be clicked and data from your available data fields is displayed in the pop-up box. To hide data fields to be shown in the pop-up display, uncheck the box next to the data field to be hidden. To add a title for the pop-up box, click "edit" next to "Title" in the bar at the top of the data fields list. Select a data field from the pulldown menu which contains the data you would like to be displayed as a title. Select "OK" to add the title field. To hide data fields to be shown in the pop-up display, uncheck the box next to the data field to be hidden. You may want to do this if your records have many fields that makes viewing in the pop-up more difficult.
  • Data fields may be reordered by clicking on the field to be moved and dragging it to the desired location.

When done, you many want to click on Preview in the green bar to see how your Map view appears. Make any adjustments you want by going back to Build in the green bar, and be sure the Map tab is selected.

3.5.9: Add a Scatterplot View

A scatter plot is a type of display using coordinates to display values for two variables for a set of data. The data is displayed as a collection of points, each having the value of one variable determining the position on the horizontal axis and the value of the other variable determining the position on the vertical axis. To set preferences for a scatterplot view:

  • Click "Add a View" next to the List View tab, then select "Scatterplot".
  • Choose the data property to represent the X axis
  • Choose the data property to represent the Y axis
  • To hide data fields to be shown in the display, uncheck the box next to the data field to be hidden. To add a title for the pop-up box, click "edit" next to "Title" in the bar at the top of the data fields list. Select a data field from the pulldown menu which contains the data to be displayed as a title. Choose the field which contains the data to be displayed as a title. Select "OK" to add the title field.
  • Data fields may be reordered by clicking on the field to be moved and dragging it to the desired location.

When done, you many want to click on Preview in the green bar to see how your Scatterplot view appears. Make any adjustments you want by going back to Build in the green bar, and be sure the Scatterplot tab is selected.

3.5.10: Add a Table View

Recollection allows you to show your data displayed in table format. To set preferences for a table view:

  • Click "Add a View" next to the List View tab, then select "Table".
  • If desired, use the radio buttons to set the order of how your data should appear in the resulting table by selecting "Asc" for ascending order and "Desc" for descending order next to the appropriate field.
  • To hide data fields to be shown in the display, uncheck the box next to the data field to be hidden.
  • Data fields may be reordered by clicking on the field to be moved and dragging it to the desired location.

When done, you many want to click on Preview in the green bar to see how your Table view appears. Make any adjustments you want by going back to Build in the green bar, and be sure the Table tab is selected.

3.5.11: Add a Timeline View

Timeline data pre-requisite: Your file must contain date information in ISO8601 format and set to type "datetime" during the Describe step in order for data points to appear in your timeline view. If your date values are not in ISO8601 format or if you are unsure if they are in the proper format, see Section 3.2.5: Augment Your Data

To set preferences for a timeline view:

  • Click "Add a View" next to the List View tab, then select "Timeline".
  • To indicate the range of time to be plotted on the Timeline for entries, choose the data fields which contain the start and end date for the range of time to be plotted using the pulldown menus at the top of the preferences menu as shown in Figure 14. If there is only one date, a point in time (rather than a line indicating a span of time) will be displayed.


    Figure 14. Choose Timeline Range

  • Time scale (e.g. day, week, month, year, etc.) (known as "time bands") can be indicated using the pulldown band menus. The time bands create a horizontal timeline with 2 bands: one time scale in the top band (such as month); and another time scale in the bottom band (such as year). The two bands scroll independently to allow for different ways to inspect the data. Note: It is usually advisable to leave these bands on the default setting of "auto". This allows the application to make a sensible guess as to scale based on the data it was provided. If results do not appear as desired, or there is a need to achieve consistency across a set of collections, the user may adjust the settings.
  • If you wish to color code items on the timeline based on a property, select the radio button next to that property. Items plotted on the timeline will appear color coded and a legend is added at the bottom of the timeline. For example, to color code based on the "Start Date" property, click the "Color" radio button to its left as shown in Figure 15


    Figure 15. Choose Timeline Color

  • Once plotted on a timeline, each of the timeline items can be clicked and your data fields will be displayed in a pop-up box. To hide data fields to be shown in the display, uncheck the box next to the data field to be hidden. To add a title for the pop-up box, click "edit" next to "Title" in the bar at the top of the data fields list. Select a data field from the pulldown menu which contains the data to be displayed as a title. Select "OK" to add the title field. To hide data fields to be shown in the display, uncheck the box next to the data field to be hidden.
  • Data fields may be reordered by clicking on the field to be moved and dragging it to the desired location.

When done, you many want to click on Preview in the green bar to see how your Timeline view appears. Make any adjustments you want by going back to Build in the green bar, and be sure the Timeline tab is selected.

3.5.12: Add a Pie Chart View

Click "Add a View" next to the List View tab, then select "Pie Chart". Since view preferences can be selected directly in your finished pie chart view, there is little to configure for this view. Data that would display well in a pie chart view in any spreadsheet program is a good candidate for the Pie Chart view.

  • If you wish to hide data fields to be shown in the display, uncheck the box next to the data field to be hidden.
  • Data fields may be reordered by clicking on the field to be moved and dragging it to the desired location.

When done, you many want to click on Preview in the green bar to see how your Pie Chart view appears. Make any adjustments you want by going back to Build in the green bar, and be sure the Pie Chart tab is selected.

3.5.13: Delete a View

It is simple to delete a view during the Build process if you decide that it is no longer needed. To delete a view which has been added during the Build process:

  • Click the down arrow next to the view to be deleted.
  • Click "Delete".
  • The view disappears from the Builder screen.

3.5.14: Rename a View

Views are given default names by Recollection, but these can be changed during the Build process if needed. To change the name of a view:

  • Click the down arrow next to the view to be renamed.
  • Click "Rename".
  • Type the updated view name in the text box provided.
  • Hit enter / return on the keyboard to complete the task.

3.5.15: Reorder Your Views

"List" views set as the default view, but you may move another view into the default position so it appears first in your Recollection View. To change the default view:

  • Click on the tab of the view that you would like to be the default, and drag it to the first position (far left). See Figure 16 below which shows the Map view moved to the default position.


Figure 16. Change Default View

3.5.16: Change Background Theme

Recollection allows you to choose from a list of background themes to customize the colors, look and feel of your published Recollection View. Themes can be changed in the Describe, Build, or Preview phase by clicking on the "Theme" pulldown menu near the top right corner of the page.


Figure 17. Change Background Theme

3.6 Preview Your Recollection View

Once all data and formatting options have been set as desired, the "Preview" steps shows what the final version will look like once published. This is a functional interface so you may test all your facets and navigation. Click "Preview" in the progress band toward the top of the screen to proceed to this step.

Recollection Views can be modified as needed prior to publishing. If the preview does not produce the desired results, return to the Describe and Build steps to modify view as needed. Click on "Preview" to see the results of the modifications and continue until the preview matches your desired results.

3.7 Publish Your Recollection View

Once the desired look and feel has been achieved, the Recollection View needs to be published in order to be shared with others. A URL to your new collection will be provided and it is live and active immediately. To publish a Recollection view:

  • Click "Publish" in the green progress band shown during the Build process.
  • A URL with the address of the newly published Recollection View will be displayed.
  • Clicking on the URL will display the Recollection View which is now ready for use.
  • Your newly published Recollection View will also be accessible via the Views tab.

3.8 Working With Recollection Views

Once you have created a Recollection View, you may want to inspect, edit or delete it. To perform any of these functions, visit your Home Page or the Views tab and locate the Recollection View with which to work.

You also have permissions to see (but not edit or delete) Recollection Views created by others. To do this, visit the profile page belonging to the creator of the Recollection View of interest and click on the linked name of the view you would like to inspect.

3.8.1 Inspect an Existing Recollection View

To inspect an existing Recollection view:

  • Locate the Recollection view to be inspected in your Home Page or the Views tab.
  • Click on the linked name of the view to be inspected.
  • You will be directed to a read-only version of the view.

3.8.2 Edit an Existing Recollection View

To edit an existing Recollection view:

  • Locate the Recollection View to be edited in your Home Page or the Views tab.
  • Click the "Edit" link next to the view to be edited.
  • You will be directed to the Build process where changes can be made as desired. Once changes are made they can be saved by proceeding to the Publish step.

3.8.3 Delete a Recollection View

To delete an existing Recollection View:

  • Locate the Recollection view to be deleted in your Home Page or the Views tab.
  • Click the "Delete" link next to the view to be deleted.
  • You will be asked if you are sure you want to deleted the view. Click "OK" to delete the view or "Cancel" if you decide you do not want to proceed with this action.

3.9 Create a Recollection View from an Existing Data Set

Recollection allows for multiple collections or views to be created for the same data set. To create a new collection using an existing data set:

  • Locate the data set to be used in the list shown on your Home Page or on the Data tab.
  • Click the "Build" link next to the data set you would like to use as the basis for your new view.
  • Follow the steps outlined 3.5: Build Your Recollection View From a New Data Set to create a new view.

3.10 Delete a Published Recollection View

To delete a published Recollection view:

  • Locate the collection on the Data tab.
  • Click "Delete".
  • After confirming the delete prompt, the Recollection View is removed from the list on your Home Page. This action cannot be undone.

4. Embedding a Recollection View in Another Web Site

To embed a Recollection view into a page on another site:

  • Click the "Embed" button at the top right of your published Recollection view.
  • Copy the code snippet in the box that appears.
  • Locate the HTML page where you would like to place the Recollection view and place it into edit mode.
  • Paste the code snippet in the HTML at the precise location where you would like the Recollection view to appear.
  • Save your html file. Once you refresh your page, the Recollection view will appear.

The primary attributes of an embedding environment that will affect the display of an embedded data view are the layout mechanism and the width allotment the environment grants the embedded display. CSS styling may have an impact as well.

Embedding is designed to be as self-contained as possible to avoid being affected by its surrounding environment. The layout is primarily achieved through a combination of CSS floats and, inside Exhibit, tables. This suggests that environments that rely wholly on CSS for layout by way of floats may have a small chance of not holding the embedded view properly, but it's more probable the two systems can work together. CSS layouts based on other mechanisms, like relative or absolute positioning, may have more problems; fixed/percentage-width layouts will depend on the width allotment (see below). Table-based layouts are a subset of fixed/percentage-width layouts.

The embedded view will take up the full width of whatever element it is placed in. It is possible to place an embedded view in an extremely narrow element, but the view display will suffer in constrained spaces. Rough suggestions for width allotment for different view canvases are: 725 pixels wide for three columns, 490 pixels wide for two column, 375 pixels wide for one column. Font size and which views are used will have a heavy impact on the width required.

CSS styling is a broad topic, from colors to backgrounds to font sizes. The embedded view's stylesheets should not affect the rest of the embedding page. Exhibit is styled as black on white by default; pages that place bright text on darker backgrounds may need to consider styling the view themselves to achieve consistency using a tool like Firebug to discover the appropriate selectors.

Problems should be reported to ndiippaccess@loc.gov so the embedding scripts can be adjusted to compensate.

Note the CSS styling on Recollection will not transfer in totality to the embedded display as some of the styling is Recollection-specific. Embedded displays should instead be styled according to the user's needs. jQuery UI and 960 are both partially utilized, and the hooks provided by each can be used for styling regions of the embedded display.

5. Settings: Managing Your Account

Setting up your account helps you to get the most out of Recollection. Doing so helps you find and connect with people you know to share data and views in Recollection. It also helps to keep you up to date with what's going on in the system. This walks you through the key steps for setting up and managing your account.

You can manage your account settings from the Settings page (Figure 18) accessible via the link at the top right corner of every Recollection page when you are logged in.


Figure 18. Settings Page

5.1 Verify or Change an Email Address

Email addresses are your way of keeping in touch with what's going on in the Recollection system via notifications and allow you to reset your password if needed. When you sign up for Recollection we will send a verification email to the email address from which your signup request was sent. To verify your email address, simply click on the link provided in the email. You will be directed to a page which says "Email Confirmed". Multiple email addresses can be added if you would like to receive communications in several accounts.

If you did not verify or enter an email address at signup time, you can do so by visiting the Settings page accessible via a link at the top right corner of every page, once you are logged in. Click "re-send verification email" if you cannot find the original message. Then go to your mail account and click on the link to complete the verification process.

To change your email address, click on the E-Mail Addresses tab accessible via the Settings page. New email addresses can be associated with your account as needed by simply typing them in the box provided and clicking the "Add" button.

To delete an email address, click the "remove" link next to the address that is no longer required. Note: You cannot delete your primary email address. If the address marked as primary is no longer needed, add a new email address and once it has been verified, mark this address as primary. You may now delete the old primary email address.

Recollection email privacy policy: Your email address is simply used as a tool to help us communicate with you. We promise not to share or sell it.

5.2 Associate an OpenID

OpenID is an open, decentralized standard for user authentication and access control, allowing users to log onto many services with the same digital identity. It replaces the common login process that uses a user name and a password, by allowing a user to log in once and gain access to multiple software systems.

You may choose to associate an existing OpenID to your account and remove this association at any time. Note, however, that if you choose to authenticate using OpenID the first time you use Recollection and do not create a user name and password, OpenID login will be your only option.

To associate a new OpenID with your account, visit the OpenID Associations tab via the Settings page. Simply type the OpenID into the text box and click "Authenticate and Associate with this Account" button.

5.3 Change Password

To change your password, click the change password tab on the Settings page. Enter your current password, then your new password twice. Click the "Change password" button to finalize the update.

Lost your password? Click on "Forgot password?" on the login page. If you have provided an email address, you will be emailed a new temporary password. Please log in and change this password to a permanent one ASAP.

5.4 Set Timezone

Set your timezone so that receive and sent time for notices is localized to your timezone. To do this, visit the Timezone tab on the Account page, select the proper timezone from the pulldown menu and click "Change my timezone".

5.5 Change Notice Preferences

To change your preferences for the email notices you receive, visit the Notices tab via the Settings page. Checking or unchecking the boxes provided allows you to control the types of email notification you will receive.

5.6 Add/Change an Avatar or Gravatar

Recollection uses the Gravatar service to allow you to add an image that will be associated with your profile throughout the site. A gravatar, or "globally recognized avatar", is an image that follows you from site to site appearing beside your name for those sites who support its use. Alternatively, you can simply upload an image from your desktop to use as your avatar within Recollection.

If you do not have a gravatar and wish to create one, you can visit the Gravatar site.

If you prefer to add an avatar from your desktop:

  • Go to your home page by clicking the "Home" link at the top of any page.
  • Click the "replace" link which appears when you mouse over the square image box in the profile section.
  • Upload a photo from your desktop to use as your avatar by clicking "Choose File", selecting your file and accepting it. Please note that we support uploading of JPG, GIF, BMP, and PNG files. The maximum file size is 400KB.
  • Your new avatar will appear immediately. You may upload multiple avatars and select a new default avatar as desired.

5.7 Subscribe to News Feeds

Internet news feeds are formatted text files that are accessible at Web addresses to help you find news information. The most common formats are RSS and Atom. News organizations use news feeds to update people with the latest news information. Recollection uses them to update people regarding the latest data files uploaded and latest views created. You can track the latest data sets and views created across the entire site or by a particular user.

To subscribe to news feeds for the Recollection site:

  • From anywhere on the site, click the RSS icon at the right side of the browser address bar.
  • Select "Subscribe to 'Latest Data Views News Feed'" or "Subscribe to 'Latest Data News Feed'" depending on your preference.
  • You will be redirected to a page showing the results of your subscription choice.

To subscribe to news feeds for a specific Recollection user:

  • From the profile page of the user, click the RSS icon at the right side of the browser address bar.
  • Select "Subscribe to 'Latest Data Views News Feed for USERNAME'" or "Subscribe to 'Latest Data Feed for USERNAME'" depending on your preference.
  • You will be redirected to a page showing the results of your subscription choice.

5.8 Fill Out Your Profile

Profiles are a way to tell the Recollection community a little bit about yourself. You can enter your full name, some text about your interests, your location and a web site URL. Other users will be able to see your profile as they encounter you within the Recollection community.

To add information to your profile:

  • Visit your home page shown in Figure 19 by clicking on the "Home" link available at the top right corner of every page.
  • Click the "Edit" button found near the center of the screen.
  • Type in your profile information.
  • Click the "update" button.

You can update your profile information at any time in the future by clicking on the "Edit" link on your Home page.


Figure 19. My Home Page

6. Participating in the Recollection Community

Recollection offers social and community features to allow you to connect and share data with individuals and groups with similar interests. The community allows you to find people you know, invite them to connect, create an interest group, or join an existing group.

The social components of Recollection can be accessed from many different parts of the site which are described in more detail below.

6.1 Find People

To find people to connect with, visit the Users tab and click on the "All Users" tab. This directs you to a list of Recollection users ordered by the date they joined the site. You may scroll or search to find users of interest. To find out more about each user, click on their user name to see their profile.

6.2 Invite Someone to Connect

Once you've located someone you want to connect with, visit their profile page. Add a personalize message in the text box or use the default message provided, and simply click on the green "Invite" button on their profile page. The invitation is sent by email as a connection request. Once approved by the invitee, you are connected. The new connection's avatar or gravatar will show up in the list on your Home Page under "Connections".

6.3 Join an Existing Group

You can find new groups to join by either browsing or searching the list of groups shown on the All Groups tab. Once you have located the group you want to join, click on its linked name. This takes you to the Group page where you may see a list of group members and discussions. Group members are shown in the top right portion of the screen.

To become a member, click the "Join" button. If you decide to leave the group at a later time, you may click the "Leave" button shown on this page to exit the group.


Figure 20. Join Some Groups

6.4 Start a Group

Anyone with an account can start a group on Recollection. A group is typically created to connect people around some common point of interest.

To make your own group:

  • Visit the Groups page by clicking on the tab toward the top right corner of the screen. You will be taken to the "Your Groups" tab where you can see a list of all the groups in which you participate currently.
  • Click on the "All Groups" tab.
  • Click on the "Create a new Group" button.
  • Enter a name for the new group in the box provided.
  • Enter a "slug" in the box provided. A slug is a short version of the group name consisting only of letters, numbers, underscores and hyphens. It usually does not contain spaces. (Sample: for a group names "Use Cases Group" the slug might be "usecases") The slug is used to link the group from various places within the site.
  • Enter a description of the group's topic or purpose. This will display to other users on the site who might be interested in joining.
  • Click the "Create" button to launch your group.

6.5 Start a New Group Discussion

To start a new discussion visit the group page where you want to kick off the discussion and click on the "Topic" tab which appears next to the tab with the group's name on it. Click the button "Create New Topic", add the requested information and click the "Create New Topic" button to start your discussion thread.

6.6 Participate in an Existing Group Discussion

To participate in an existing group discussion listed on a group page, click on the title of the discussion topic. Enter your discussion points in the text box at the bottom of the screen and click the green Post Response button.

You can also respond to a particular person's comment by clicking on the Reply to This Post link, entering your response, and clicking on the green Post Response button.

Thank you for your interest in Recollection!

Recollection is currently in invitational Beta and only accessible to NDIIPP partners. To gain access to Recollection with an authorized account, please send us an email (including your desired username) to ndiippaccess@loc.gov.

Our systems team will respond within 24 hours with your account information.

Recollection is a tool for:

  • Creating new interfaces, relationships, and access points for digital resources
  • Exposing data for sharing and combining with other resources
  • Exploring and managing data for digital resources
  1. Explore digital resources
    • This icon indicates a Recollection interface:
    • Find new relationships
    • Discover new access points
    • Export filtered results
  2. Upload your own digital resources
    • Sign up for an account
    • Create new views, relationships and access points
    • Direct traffic back to your own collections
    • Control access

From the National Digital Information Infrastructure Preservation Program. Learn more about this project, NDIIPP, or Zepheira.
